rename.from: Extend reduction from forecasting to regression to handle multivariate data
rename.to: Extend reduction from forecasting to regression to handle exogenous data

issue.title: [DOC] Add example of vector forecasting

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body: #### Could you add an example of multivariate forecasting?

body:
The code is here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/sktime/forecasting/compose/_reduce.py

The current code isn't great because:
* convoluted class hierarchy makes it hard to follow and extend
* inefficient for-loops for data transformations 

I suggest we break up the code into simpler classes using stand-alone functions for the data transformations. 

@SebasKoel has done some work already here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/390 (see e.g. `create_lag_matrix`) 

I suggest we start with the reduction to the simpler tabular regression setting (basically scikit-learn, i.e. transforming time series into 2d numpy array) and work on the time series regression setting (3d numpy) once the tabular setting is working. 

What we want to be able to do in the end is something like this: 

```python
from sktime.forecasting.all import * 
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor

y, X = load_longley()
y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X)
fh = ForecastingHorizon(y_test.index, is_relative=False)

regressor = RandomForestRegressor()
forecaster = ReducedRegressionForecaster(regressor, window_length=10, strategy="recursive")
forecaster.fit(y_train, X_train)
y_pred = forecaster.predict(fh, X=X_test)
```

Note that we not only create lagged values for the target series (`y`) but also the exogenous data (`X`). We then pass all lagged values in the required 2d numpy array to scikit-learn regressor.
Any chance there's an ETA on this? This seems like a pretty essential feature for people deciding which forecasting library to use.
Hi @bradyneal, yes I agree! Do you want to take a look at this? What other libraries are you considering?

Maybe in the future (lots of uncertainty), but not right now, unfortunately. PyTorch Forecasting, GluonTS, and NeuralProphet. From a preliminary look, `sktime` seems the best in terms of how well designed it is, its broad scope, and lots of great classical forecasters :), but not in other aspects such as exogenous data support (beyond AutoARIMA), more advanced hyperparameter tuning, and SOTA neural models (not in sktime-dl).
@bradyneal yeah, I agree, still early days for sktime and lots of work to be done. What are you looking for for hyper-parameter tuning?

Simple integration with a more efficient hyperparameter tuning library such as Optuna (e.g. PyTorch Forecasting does this). Random search is nice to have over grid search, but I don't think either of them really compare to more modern hyperparameter tuning algorithms. However, I don't think sklearn even has this integration.
Interesting, wasn't aware of Optuna, will take a look!

Perhaps we should make the reduction compositor more pipeline like, allowing users to pass transformers to specify how to transform the data. In the end, this reduction is a kind of pipeline. This way we could also handle different transformations for different (exogenous) variables. 

Something like this:  
```python
forecaster = ReducedRegressionForecaster(regressor=regressor, transformers=[
    ("t1", SlidingWindowTransformer(window_length, ...), [0]), 
    ("t2", SlidingWindowTransformer(window_length, ...), [1])
], strategy="recursive", ...)
```
with `[0]` referring to the target series and `[1]` to an exogenous variable, together with a new series-to-tabular transformer scitype for the `SlidingWindowTransformer`.
Hm, why would you want to do this instead of `ReducedRegressionForecaster(Pipeline(stuff))` where `Pipeline` is directly from `sklearn`?

@fkiraly as I understand it, that wouldn't work, because you need the sliding-window transformation to go to the tabular format required for the sklearn pipeline. The regressor itself could of course be a sklearn pipeline.

@Lovkush-A here's some code how we could handle exogenous variables in the sliding-window transformation, it also speeds up the transformation. 

```python
import numpy as np
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.datasets import load_longley
y, X = load_longley()
y = y.astype(np.float)
X = X.astype(np.float)
X.index = y.index
y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X)
print(y_train.shape, y_test.shape, X_train.shape, X_test.shape)
from sktime.forecasting.all import *
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
reducer = ReducedRegressionForecaster(RandomForestRegressor(), window_length=3)
window_length = 10
series = pd.Series(np.arange(10_000), dtype=np.float)
# our current approach
reducer._cv = SlidingWindowSplitter(start_with_window=True, window_length=window_length)
%timeit reducer._transform(series)
Xa, ya = reducer._transform(series)
Xa = Xa[:, ::-1]
# statsmodels functionality
from statsmodels.tsa.tsatools import lagmat, lagmat2ds
def create_lag_matrix_statsmodels(y, X=None, window_length=10, **kwargs):
    if X is None:
        ret = lagmat(y, window_length, trim="backward", use_pandas=False, **kwargs)
    else:
        ret = lagmat2ds(pd.concat([y, X], axis=1), window_length, trim="backward", use_pandas=False, **kwargs)
    ret = ret[:-window_length + 1, :]
    return ret[:, 0].reshape(-1, 1), ret[:, 1:]
%timeit create_lag_matrix_statsmodels(series, window_length=window_length + 1)
yb, Xb = create_lag_matrix_statsmodels(series, window_length=window_length + 1)
np.testing.assert_array_equal(ya, yb)
np.testing.assert_array_equal(Xa, Xb)
# revision of our approach
def create_lag_matrix(x, window_length):
    # input checks
    x = np.asarray(x)
    if x.ndim == 1:
        x = x.reshape(-1, 1)
    # time series tabularisation
    n_timepoints, n_variables = x.shape
    lm = np.zeros((n_timepoints + window_length, n_variables * (window_length + 1)))
    for k in range(window_length + 1):
        a = window_length - k
        b = n_timepoints + window_length - k
        c = n_variables * (window_length - k)
        d = n_variables * (window_length - k + 1)
        lm[a:b, c:d] = x
    # truncate
    lm = lm[window_length:-window_length]
    # separate y, X
    y = lm[:, 0].reshape(-1, 1)
    X = lm[:, 1:]
    return y, X
%timeit create_lag_matrix(series, window_length)
yc, Xc = create_lag_matrix(series, window_length)
np.testing.assert_array_equal(yc, ya)
np.testing.assert_array_equal(Xc, Xa)
```

issue.title: Add handling of exogeneous data to forecasting reductions

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
see #345 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Allow reduction of forecasting to regression to handle exogenous data

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->


#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.
